meanings.definition: a place where people stay in tents or other temporary structures:

meanings.definition: to put up a tent and stay in it for a short while, for example while on holiday:

meanings.definition: using bright colours, loud sounds, unusual behaviour, etc. in a humorous way:

meanings.definition: a place where people stay in tents or other temporary structures:

meanings.definition: A camp is also a place where people, esp. military people, are trained, where military prisoners are kept, or where people have to live temporarily.

meanings.definition: a light bed that can be folded so that it can be easily carried and stored

meanings.definition: a planned series of activities that are intended to achieve a particular aim:

meanings.definition: to organize a series of activities to try to achieve something:

meanings.definition: efforts to change the rules on how political campaigns can be paid for, with the aim of making them fairer:

meanings.definition: someone whose job is to give people advice and information about what type of work they could do or how they could progress to a better job:
examples: He is a career counselor in California who advises clients about career changes.

meanings.definition: the process of learning and improving your skills so that you can do your job better and progress to better jobs:
examples: We provide career development through a call centre NVQ programme.
A mentor can be particularly helpful for your career development.

meanings.definition: an event at which people looking for a job can meet possible employers:
examples: The school organized a two-day career fair involving 65 companies.

meanings.definition: a series of increasingly important or well-paid jobs that someone does during their working life:
examples: Success is often measured in terms of climbing the career ladder.
Many astronauts moved to NASA because it was the next step up the career ladder.

meanings.definition: a series of jobs from the lower paid with less responsibility to the highest paid with the most responsibility within a company or particular profession:
examples: If someone has a good work ethic, they should move up the career ladder.

meanings.definition: a change that you make in order to get a better job or to have better success in your job:
examples: Moving to a smaller company turned out to be a good career move.

meanings.definition: help with finding another job that is provided by a company for an employee, usually an executive, whose job has ended or who is leaving the company:
examples: Providing career outplacement services to departing employees is the responsible thing to do.

meanings.definition: the way that you progress in your work, either in one job or in a series of jobs:
examples: I don't know what future career path might suit me but I'm told I relate well to people.
She followed an unusual career path, in that she retrained relatively late in life.

meanings.definition: the process of making progress to better jobs:
examples: There were limited opportunities for career progression in my job.
It was clear that this secondment would be extremely positive for my career progression.

meanings.definition: the possibility of being successful in your working life:
examples: I took this new job because I felt that the career prospects were much better.
Will going travelling for a year damage my career prospects?

meanings.definition: the series of jobs, from less senior to more senior jobs, that people can progress through in a company or type of work:
examples: Both the pay and the career structure of nursing have been improved.

meanings.definition: a woman who considers her job and success in her job to be very important in her life
A career-defining moment or action is one that is very important in making someone successful in their job or in deciding how they will be remembered:
examples: The movie features Bruce Willis in his career-defining role.
a career-defining speech/performance/victory

meanings.definition: A career-limiting action or fault is one that damages your chances of being successful in your job:
examples: Career-limiting habits you should avoid include unreliability and resistance to change.

past simple and past participle of 
        
         carry
to hold something or someone with your hands, arms, or on your back and transport it, him, or her from one place to another:
examples: Would you like me to carry your bag for you?
She carried her tired child upstairs to bed.
These books are too heavy for me to carry.
We only had a small suitcase, so we were able to carry it onto the plane.
Robson injured his leg in the second half of the match and had to be carried off.
Thieves broke the shop window and carried off (= removed) jewellery worth thousands of pounds.

meanings.definition: to move someone or something from one place to another:
examples: Rubbish left on the beach during the day is carried away (= removed) at night by the tide.
The bus that was involved in the accident was carrying children to school.
The Brooklyn Bridge carries traffic across the East River from Brooklyn to Manhattan.
Police think that the body was carried down the river (= was transported by the flow of the river).
Underground cables carry electricity to all parts of the city.

meanings.definition: to have something with you all the time:
examples: He will carry the memory of the accident with him (= will remember the accident) for ever.
Police officers in Britain do not usually carry guns.

meanings.definition: to have something as a part, quality, or result:
examples: I'm afraid my opinion doesn't carry any weight with (= influence) my boss.
All cigarette packets carry a government health warning.
Our cars carry a twelve-month guarantee.
His speech carried so much conviction that I had to agree with him.
In some countries, murder carries the death penalty.

meanings.definition: to take something from one person or thing and give it to another person or thing:
examples: Malaria is a disease carried by mosquitoes.

meanings.definition: to support the weight of something without moving or breaking:
examples: The weight of the cathedral roof is carried by two rows of pillars.

meanings.definition: to support, keep in operation, or make a success:
examples: We can no longer afford to carry people who don't work as hard as they should.
Luckily they had a very strong actor in the main part and he managed to carry the whole play (= make a success of it through his own performance).

meanings.definition: to win the support, agreement, or sympathy of a group of people:
examples: The bosses' plans to reorganize the company won't succeed unless they can carry the workforce with them.

meanings.definition: to give approval, especially by voting:
examples: The motion/proposal/resolution/bill was carried by 210 votes to 160.

meanings.definition: (of a newspaper or radio or television broadcast) to contain particular information:
examples: This morning's newspapers all carry the same story on their front page.

meanings.definition: to be able to reach or travel a particular distance:
examples: The sound of the explosion carried for miles.

meanings.definition: to develop or continue something:

meanings.definition: to put a number into another column when doing addition

meanings.definition: to offer something for sale:
examples: Does this store carry camping equipment?

meanings.definition: to continue doing something, or to cause something to continue:
examples: Let's carry on this discussion at some other time.
Carry on the good work!
Sorry to interrupt, please carry on (with what you were saying).
You just have to carry on as if nothing's happened.
Steve just carried on playing on his computer.

meanings.definition: to behave in an uncontrolled, excited, or anxious (= worried and nervous) way:
examples: The children have been carrying on all day.

meanings.definition: to have a sexual relationship:
examples: Is it true that Rachel and Marcus have been carrying on (with each other)?

meanings.definition: behaviour that shows you are annoyed, worried, not satisfied, or excited, usually more than the situation deserves:
examples: There was a real carry-on when Pat was found kissing Ashley.

meanings.definition: a small case or bag that you take onto a plane with you
relating to things that you take onto a plane with you:
examples: All carry-on baggage must be stored under your seat or in the overhead compartments.

meanings.definition: to behave in an excited or anxious way that is not controlled:
examples: The kids have been carrying on all day.

meanings.definition: to continue to do or be involved with something:
examples: Dianne is carrying on the family tradition by becoming a lawyer.
You’ve got to carry on as though nothing happened.

meanings.definition: small enough to be carried onto an aircraft with you:
examples: All carry-on luggage must be stowed under the seat in front of you or in one of the overhead compartments.

meanings.definition: to be in love with someone:
examples: Terry has been carrying a torch for Liz for years, but she seems not to notice.

meanings.definition: to be able to sing the correct musical sounds of a tune:
examples: Neither of my brothers can carry a tune, but my sister is a good singer.

meanings.definition: to be able to sing the correct musical sounds of a tune:

meanings.definition: to cause someone to become very excited and to lose control:
examples: The crowd were carried away by his passionate speech.

meanings.definition: to move something or someone away from a particular place:
examples: Rubbish left on the beach during the day is carried away at night by the tide.
The eggs roll out of the cages onto a conveyor belt that carries them away.
Be careful when swimming in the river as the current is strong enough to carry you away.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to become very excited and to lose control:
examples: I got carried away and spent too much money.

meanings.definition: to help someone be able to deal with a difficult situation:
examples: The soldiers' courage carried them through.

meanings.definition: to complete something successfully:
examples: It is doubtful whether it will be possible to carry through the education reforms.

meanings.definition: to help someone in a difficult situation:
examples: We have only enough money to carry us through the next 3 months.

meanings.definition: to bring to a successful end; to complete:
examples: We are determined to carry our plans through to completion.

meanings.definition: to include an amount of money in a later set of calculations:
examples: The balance in our account for June includes £5,000 carried over from May.

meanings.definition: to succeed in doing or achieving something difficult:
examples: I thought he carried off the part of Hamlet with great skill.
She was nervous about giving a talk to her colleagues, but she carried it off very well.

meanings.definition: to remove something or someone by physically holding them in your hands or arms, or by using physical force, and transporting them to another place:
examples: Thieves broke the shop window and carried off jewellery worth thousands of pounds.
Soldiers were reported to have rounded up civilians and carried them off somewhere.

meanings.definition: to succeed in doing or achieving something, esp. when this is difficult:
examples: I wouldn’t dare wear anything that outrageous, but Michelle carried it off wonderfully.

meanings.definition: to remove something:
examples: Thieves broke the store window and carried off jewelry worth thousands of dollars.

meanings.definition: to do or complete something, especially that you have said you would do or that you have been told to do:
examples: Dr Carter is carrying out research on early Christian art.
The hospital is carrying out tests to find out what's wrong with her.
Our soldiers carried out a successful attack last night.
It is hoped that the kidnappers will not carry out their threat to kill the hostages.
Don't blame me, I'm only carrying out my orders/instructions.

meanings.definition: to perform or complete a job or activity; to fulfill:
examples: I was elected to carry out a program, the governor said, and I have every intention of carrying it out.

meanings.definition: to use or do something at a later time than planned:
examples: The performance has had to be carried over to/till next week because the repairs to the theatre aren't finished yet.

meanings.definition: If something from one situation carries over or is carried over into another situation, it is allowed to affect the other situation:
examples: I try not to let my problems at work carry over into my private life.

meanings.definition: to move to or to come from a place or time:
examples: I try not to let my problems at work carry over into my private life.
The competitive balance of the regular season has been carried over to the playoffs.

meanings.definition: to copy an amount of money on an earlier page or column of an account, or to move it to an earlier accounting period:
examples: Companies operating at a loss can carry back current losses to periods in which profits were made to get a tax refund.
You have until January 31 to carry back pension contributions to the previous tax year and claim unused tax relief.

meanings.definition: to copy an amount of money on the next page or column of an account, or to move it to a later accounting period:
examples: The shortfall will leave no cash to carry forward to the next budget year.

meanings.definition: to be responsible for making progress with a task:
examples: "We're the ones who have carried the ball in the war on drugs," he said.

meanings.definition: to take the blame or responsibility for something that is wrong or has not succeeded:
examples: As usual, I was left to carry the can.

meanings.definition: to gain victory or be successful:
examples: But what if his Democratic rival had carried the day?

meanings.definition: a method of investing in which an investor borrows money at a low interest rate to buy an investment that is likely to produce a much higher amount of profit. Carry trades are often used by investors in foreign currencies:
examples: The carry trade is mostly driven by Japanese individuals trying to improve the return on their savings.

meanings.definition: to have respect, influence, trust, or importance:
examples: His words obviously carried weight with them.

Surely the sworn evidence of the 100 women involved carries some weight?

meanings.definition: In cricket, if one of the two batters (= players who try to hit the ball and score) who start a team's innings (= turn to play) carries their bat, they continue to play without being put out until all of the other players on the team have been put out:
examples: The opener carried his bat for the second consecutive game.
She carried her bat to score a batting century whilst all the other batters around her struggled.

meanings.definition: to supply something to a place or person that already has a lot of that particular thing:
examples: Exporting pine to Scandinavia seems like carrying coals to Newcastle.

a large motor vehicle with seats along the sides that face each other
the practice of treating a company's present profit or loss as if it happened in an earlier period:

meanings.definition: an amount that is copied from a later column of numbers or a later accounting period to an earlier one
a rule that allows an employee to count this year's payments into their pension fund as if they were made in the previous tax year:

meanings.definition: a container shaped like a rectangular box with two handles, in which a baby can be carried
the practice of treating a company's present profit or loss as if it happened in a later period:

to hold something or someone with your hands, arms, or on your back and transport it, him, or her from one place to another:
examples: Would you like me to carry your bag for you?
She carried her tired child upstairs to bed.
These books are too heavy for me to carry.
We only had a small suitcase, so we were able to carry it onto the plane.
Robson injured his leg in the second half of the match and had to be carried off.
Thieves broke the shop window and carried off (= removed) jewellery worth thousands of pounds.

meanings.definition: to move someone or something from one place to another:
examples: Rubbish left on the beach during the day is carried away (= removed) at night by the tide.
The bus that was involved in the accident was carrying children to school.
The Brooklyn Bridge carries traffic across the East River from Brooklyn to Manhattan.
Police think that the body was carried down the river (= was transported by the flow of the river).
Underground cables carry electricity to all parts of the city.

meanings.definition: to have something with you all the time:
examples: He will carry the memory of the accident with him (= will remember the accident) for ever.
Police officers in Britain do not usually carry guns.

meanings.definition: to have something as a part, quality, or result:
examples: I'm afraid my opinion doesn't carry any weight with (= influence) my boss.

Our cars carry a twelve-month guarantee.
His speech carried so much conviction that I had to agree with him.

The salesclerk said they didn't carry (= have a supply of) sportswear.

meanings.definition: to take something from one person or thing and give it to another person or thing:
examples: Malaria is a disease carried by mosquitoes.

meanings.definition: to support the weight of something without moving or breaking:
examples: The weight of the cathedral roof is carried by two rows of pillars.

meanings.definition: to support, keep in operation, or make a success:
examples: We can no longer afford to carry people who don't work as hard as they should.
Luckily they had a very strong actor in the main part and he managed to carry the whole play (= make a success of it through his own performance).

meanings.definition: to win the support, agreement, or sympathy of a group of people:
examples: The bosses' plans to reorganize the company won't succeed unless they can carry the workforce with them.

meanings.definition: to give approval, especially by voting:
examples: The motion/proposal/resolution/bill was carried by 210 votes to 160.

meanings.definition: (of a newspaper or radio or television broadcast) to contain particular information:
examples: This morning's newspapers all carry the same story on their front page.

meanings.definition: to be able to reach or travel a particular distance:
examples: The sound of the explosion carried for miles.
The ball carried high into the air and landed on the other side of the fence.

meanings.definition: to develop or continue something:
examples: We must end here, but we can carry today's discussion forward at our next meeting.

If we carry this argument to its logical conclusion, we realize that further investment is not a good idea.

meanings.definition: to put a number into another column when doing addition

examples: Every running back wants to carry the ball.

meanings.definition: in ice hockey and football, to control the puck or ball and move forward toward the goal with it:
examples: He carried the puck into the Vancouver zone on the left side.

meanings.definition: in basketball, to put your hand underneath the ball while dribbling (= moving the ball by repeatedly hitting it against the floor with your hand) or as you start to move, which is against the rules:
examples: If you carry the ball, the referee will blow the whistle and you will lose possession.

meanings.definition: In golf, if you carry a part of the golf course (= playing area) such as a bunker, fairway, etc., you successfully hit the ball over it:
examples: The opening tee shots must try to carry the fairway bunkers at 260 yards.

meanings.definition: In cricket, if a ball carries, it does not hit the ground before being caught:
examples: The fielder wasn't sure whether the ball had carried so it was referred to the third umpire.

meanings.definition: to be pregnant with a child:

meanings.definition: arguments, facts, and reasons in support of or against something:

meanings.definition: a detailed examination of a particular process or situation over a period of time:

cast-a-look-glance-smile-etc.name: cast a look, glance, smile, etc.

meanings.definition: to look, smile, etc. in a particular direction:
examples: She cast a quick look in the rear mirror.
Throughout the whole of the evening, he didn't once cast a glance in my direction.
She cast a look behind her to make sure they weren't following her.

examples: Her father's illness had cast a shadow over the birth of her baby.

meanings.definition: to vote:
examples: All the votes in the election have now been cast and the counting has begun.

meanings.definition: to search in many different places for something that you need:

meanings.definition: to make people feel less sure about or have less trust in something or someone:

meanings.definition: Casual clothes are not formal or not suitable for special occasions:

meanings.definition: not regular or frequent; temporary or done sometimes:

meanings.definition: used to describe work that is not permanent, or workers that are not employed permanently but only when a company needs them:
examples: Most casual workers are paid by the day or hour.

meanings.definition: casual clothes are informal:
examples: Research shows that 90% of US companies now allow casual dress regularly.

meanings.definition: to make something start happening or start being successful:
examples: Will this be enough to catalyse the country's moribund industry?

meanings.definition: the process of making a chemical reaction happen more quickly by using a catalyst
something that makes a chemical reaction happen more quickly without itself being changed
an event or person that causes great change:
examples: The high suicide rate acted as a catalyst for change in the prison system.

meanings.definition: a condition, event, or person that is the cause of an important change
A catalyst is also a substance that causes or speeds a chemical reaction without itself being changed.
someone or something that causes a big change:
examples: The catalyst behind this welcome trend has been the mighty Bill Gates.
An outside leader is often needed to serve as a catalyst for change.
The Government will act as a catalyst to promote creative collaboration between businesses.

meanings.definition: making a chemical reaction happen more quickly by using a catalyst:
examples: The compounds are formed through a catalytic reaction called oxidation.

meanings.definition: a device on a car that reduces the amount of poisonous gas that is released from the exhaust
in a way that involves the use of a catalyst (= a substance that makes a chemical reaction happen more quickly without itself being changed) :
examples: That particular rock type contains minerals that are thought to be very catalytically active.
In the stratosphere, nitrous oxide catalytically destroys ozone.

meanings.definition: to make a chemical reaction happen or happen more quickly by acting as a catalyst:
examples: It was thought that only proteins could catalyze reactions in cells.

meanings.definition: to make something start happening or start being successful:
examples: Will this be enough to catalyze the country's moribund industry?

meanings.definition: a sailing boat that has two parallel hulls (= floating parts) held together by a single deck (= flat surface)
Cataphatic theology involves defining or knowing God through positive statements.
a word that refers to a word used later in a text and replaces it, for example "he" in the sentence "When he saw me, Joe smiled.":
examples: In the following sentence, the pronoun "she" (the cataphor) appears earlier than the noun "Kate" that it refers to.

meanings.definition: the use of cataphors (= words that refer to and replace other words used later in a text):
examples: An example of cataphora would be: "If you want some, there's coffee in the pot."

meanings.definition: referring to or replacing a word or phrase that is used later in a text:
examples: With cataphoric reference, you may need to read forward to understand.
anaphoric and cataphoric pronouns

meanings.definition: in a way that refers to or replaces a word or phrase that is used later in a text:
examples: In English "this" may be used both anaphorically and cataphorically.

meanings.definition: a device that can throw objects at a high speed:
examples: In the past, armies used catapults to hurl heavy stones at enemy fortifications.
On that type of aircraft carrier, a catapult was used to help launch aircraft.

meanings.definition: a Y-shaped stick or piece of metal with a piece of elastic (= material that stretches) attached to the top parts, used especially by children for shooting small stones
to throw someone or something with great force:
examples: When the two vehicles collided, he was catapulted forwards.

meanings.definition: to become famous or important very suddenly, in the process moving beyond others who had been more famous or important:
examples: The album of hit songs catapulted her almost overnight into national stardom.

meanings.definition: Something or someone that is catapulted is thrown forward with great force or speed.

past simple and past participle of 
        
         catapult
to throw someone or something with great force:
examples: When the two vehicles collided, he was catapulted forwards.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         catapult
to throw someone or something with great force:
examples: When the two vehicles collided, he was catapulted forwards.

meanings.definition: a disease in which an area of someone's eye becomes less clear so that they cannot see clearly, or the area affected in this way
a large waterfall
an area of the eye that changes to become unclear, causing a person not to see well, or this condition of the eye
a place in a river where the water falls to a lower level
a condition in which a lot of mucus is produced in the nose and throat, especially when a person has an infection, or the mucus produced
a sudden event that causes very great trouble or destruction:
examples: They were warned of the ecological catastrophe to come.

meanings.definition: a bad situation:
examples: The emigration of scientists is a catastrophe for the country.

meanings.definition: a sudden event that causes great suffering or destruction:
examples: Losing his job was a financial catastrophe for his family.
A chemical plant leak could cause an environmental catastrophe.

meanings.definition: someone who works for an insurance company and whose job is to decide how much to pay someone who has been badly affected by a serious accident or event

a type of investment that pays a high rate of interest unless there is a natural disaster, such as a flood, forest fire, etc. If this happens, the investment is lost and the money is used to help the people affected
the scientific study of situations where a process suddenly changes or stops:
examples: Catastrophe theory predicts that the world will become impossible for humans to live in.
He returned to university to do research into mathematical systems with a special interest in catastrophe theory.

meanings.definition: causing sudden and very great harm or destruction:
examples: An unchecked increase in the use of fossil fuels could have catastrophic results for the planet.
A catastrophic storm made landfall on US soil.

meanings.definition: very bad:
examples: She had to put her catastrophic Olympic performance out of her mind.

meanings.definition: in a way that is very bad, or causes very great harm:
examples: The decision was based on data that has now proved to be catastrophically inaccurate.
There is no doubt that the climate can change suddenly and even catastrophically.

meanings.definition: to think about the worst things that could possibly happen in a situation, or to consider a situation as much worse or much more serious than it really is:
examples: You must stay calm and not catastrophize.
He says that adolescents tend to catastrophize things.

meanings.definition: a state in which someone is stiff and not moving or reacting, caused by various medical conditions, including schizophrenia:
examples: Catatonia has historically been associated with schizophrenia.
Medical conditions associated with the development of catatonia include medical, neurological, and substance-induced conditions.

meanings.definition: If someone is catatonic, they are stiff and not moving or reacting, as if dead.
going badly, awkwardly, or in the wrong direction:
examples: The script is spoiled by its catawampus rhythms and its lack of consistency and plausibility.
I didn't need this, especially on a morning when everything else had already started out going cattywampus.

meanings.definition: a situation in which you have a lot of advantages or power:
examples: Throughout the technology boom of the 1990s, the company sat in the catbird seat.
This discovery puts you in the catbird seat.
She rapidly ascended to the catbird seat of co-host of the Saturday night show.

meanings.definition: a loud shout or whistle (= a high sound made by blowing) expressing disapproval, especially made by people in a crowd:
examples: He walked out of the meeting to jeers and catcalls.
The film had an angry accompaniment of shouts and catcalls from sections of the audience.

meanings.definition: a loud insulting remark or whistle (= a high sound made by blowing), usually expressing unwanted sexual interest:
examples: Catcalls and ribald suggestions followed us down the street.
There were catcalls and obscene remarks as she tried to pass the men blocking the pavement.

meanings.definition: (usually of a crowd of people) to shout or whistle (= make a high sound by blowing) in a way that expresses disapproval:
examples: He describes being catcalled every time he played.
The audience whistled, heckled, and catcalled.

meanings.definition: to call out or whistle (= make a high sound by blowing) at someone in an insulting way, usually expressing unwanted sexual interest:
examples: Male colleagues catcalled when she took the podium to speak.
I was walking through town minding my own business, when a group of young men started catcalling me.

meanings.definition: a person who calls out or whistles (= makes a high sound by blowing) at someone in an insulting way, usually expressing unwanted sexual interest:
examples: My response to catcallers is to pretend to think they are begging for money and say "Sorry, I don't have any change."
A catcaller turned nasty after she told him to go away.

meanings.definition: a person, usually in a crowd, who shouts or whistles (= makes a high sound by blowing) in a way that expresses disapproval:
examples: She sang with enough power to drown out any catcaller in the audience.

meanings.definition: the act of shouting or whistling (= making a high sound by blowing) in a way that expresses disapproval, usually by people in a crowd:
examples: There was no catcalling from our side when the other team's national anthem was played.
There is a lot of hooting, catcalling and good-natured yelling from the crowd.

meanings.definition: the action of calling out or whistling (= making a high sound by blowing) at someone in an insulting way, usually expressing unwanted sexual interest:
examples: Catcalling has never worked for any man, so why do they do it?
She encountered racist catcalling and sneers at her Guatemalan family.

meanings.definition: to take hold of something, especially something that is moving through the air:
examples: He caught hold of my arm.
I managed to catch the glass before it hit the ground.
We saw the eagle swoop from the sky to catch its prey.
Our dog ran past me and out of the house before I could catch it.
We placed saucepans on the floor to catch (= collect) the drops of water coming through the roof.
The batsman was caught (out) (= someone in the other team caught the ball when he hit it).

meanings.definition: to find and stop a person or animal that is trying to escape:
examples: Great pressure was put on the police to catch the terrorists as soon as possible.
Two armed men were caught trying to cross the frontier at night.
They were happy because they had caught a lot of fish that day.
I can see you're busy right now, so I'll catch you (= speak to you) later.

meanings.definition: to discover, see, or realize something, especially someone doing something wrong:
examples: He caught her reading his old love letters.
If the virus is caught (= discovered) in time, most patients can be successfully treated.

meanings.definition: to travel or be able to travel on an aircraft, train, bus, etc.:
examples: He always catches the 10.30 a.m. train to work.

meanings.definition: to be in time to travel on or do something:
examples: She was worried that she'd arrive too late to catch the last bus home.
You'll have to run if you want to catch the post (= send something before the post has been collected).

meanings.definition: to get an illness, especially one caused by bacteria or a virus:
examples: He caught a cold on holiday.
A lot of children in the school caught measles last term.

meanings.definition: to manage to hear or see something, so you understand or remember it:
examples: I couldn't catch what the announcer said, with all the other noise going on.
Did you catch the car's number plate?

meanings.definition: to go to a place in order to see or watch something, such as a film or show:
examples: Here are some of the exhibitions you should catch this summer.
I was home in time to catch the evening news.
Would you like to catch a movie some time?

meanings.definition: to stick somewhere, or to make something stick somewhere:
examples: The sleeve of my jacket (got) caught on the door handle and ripped.
Her hair got caught (up) in her hairdryer.

meanings.definition: to hit something, especially without intending to:
examples: Medical teams were caught in the crossfire of the opposing armies.
His head caught the edge of the table as he fell.

meanings.definition: to begin to burn:
examples: This wood's too wet, the fire won't catch.

meanings.definition: an act of catching a ball or other object that is moving through the air:
examples: I missed the catch and threw the ball back to him rather crossly.
She grabbed the glass just before it hit the floor. "Good catch," he said.

meanings.definition: the activity of throwing and catching something, usually a ball, for fun:
examples: We didn't have a ball so we played catch with a lime.
I remember games of catch in the playground when I was growing up.

meanings.definition: in sports such as cricket and baseball, an act of ending an opponent's turn to hit the ball by taking hold of a ball that they have hit before it touches the ground:
examples: Crowe made a fine catch in the outfield.
She dived full length and pulled off an amazing catch.

meanings.definition: a fish or an amount of fish caught:
examples: The fishermen were disappointed with their catch that day.
One of my best catches was a big silver salmon.

meanings.definition: a hidden problem or disadvantage:
examples: Free food? It sounds too good to be true. What's the catch?

meanings.definition: an act of noticing a mistake or problem and doing something to correct or solve it:
examples: Thanks for pointing out that the picture has the wrong caption. Good catch!
A car stopped for a traffic offence turned out to be stolen, so that was a good catch.

meanings.definition: a small device on a door, window, bag, etc. that keeps it fastened
a person who is considered to be very suitable as a romantic or marriage partner:
examples: My mother considered a doctor to be a good catch.
Her new boyfriend's not much of a catch really, is he?

meanings.definition: a feeling of stiffness in part of your body:
examples: She would complain of catch in the joints during winter.

meanings.definition: to take or get hold of a moving object, or to hold and prevent someone from getting away:
examples: She tossed him the car keys and yelled, “Catch!”
He sneaked into the fairgrounds without paying and hoped nobody would catch him.

meanings.definition: to discover, find, or become aware of something:
examples: If the disease is caught in time, most patients get well quickly.
I hope I catch all the mistakes in my term paper.

meanings.definition: to see or hear something or someone, or to understand:
examples: I’m sorry, I didn’t quite catch what you said.

meanings.definition: to travel or be able to travel on a train, bus, aircraft, etc.:
examples: He always caught the 6:05 train out of Grand Central.

meanings.definition: to get an illness:
examples: I caught a cold.

meanings.definition: a hidden problem or disadvantage:
examples: That sales price sounds too good to be true – there must be a catch to it somewhere.

meanings.definition: a small device with a movable part that is used to fasten something:
examples: The catch on the bracelet is broken.

meanings.definition: the act of taking hold of something that is thrown or comes through the air:
examples: The ball was hit well, but the centerfielder made a leaping, one-handed catch to end the game.

meanings.definition: Catch is also the activity of throwing and receiving a ball with another person:
examples: My kids are always begging me to play catch.

meanings.definition: a hidden problem or disadvantage:
examples: The catch is that during the calendar year you can only make six withdrawals from your account.

meanings.definition: a new employee that a company is very pleased to have because they are very valuable:
examples: He is a super-bright economist who is a real catch for the department.

meanings.definition: to reach someone in front of you by going faster than them:
examples: I ran after her and managed to catch up with her.
Go on to the shops without me, I'll catch you up.

meanings.definition: to reach the same quality or standard as someone or something else:
examples: Will Western industry ever catch up with Japanese innovations?
He was off school for a while and is finding it hard to catch up.

meanings.definition: to do something you did not have time to do earlier:
examples: She's staying late at the office to catch up with/on some reports.

meanings.definition: to learn or discuss the latest news:
examples: Let's go for a coffee - I need to catch up on all the gossip.

meanings.definition: to reach someone or something by moving faster than the other person or thing:
examples: She is really fast, and I couldn’t catch up with her.
fig. We’re a young, growing company, and we’re trying to catch up to the competition.

meanings.definition: to talk with someone you know in order to exchange news or information:
examples: By the time coffee came, R.J. and Angelo had caught up a little bit.

meanings.definition: the activity of trying to do as well as a competitor or of trying to reach a level of achievement:
examples: Having started his fund-raising late, he had to play catch-up if he wanted to get enough money for his political campaign.

meanings.definition: to do something you did not have time to do earlier:
examples: We're trying to catch up on paperwork this week.
Sam drove straight to the office to catch up with the mountain of work she had waiting for her.
I find the backlog of freelance work sometimes builds up, and I always seem to be catching up.

meanings.definition: to reach the same level or quality as someone or something else:
examples: It was years before demand for office space caught up with supply.
Their newer competitors are threatening to catch them up.
He argued that their pay had fallen behind workers in comparable industries and needed to catch up.

meanings.definition: to find out the most recent information or news:
examples: He used the train journey to catch up with the morning news.
Let's have a coffee next week and catch up.

meanings.definition: the process of trying to reach the same standard or quality as someone or something else when they have become more advanced or successful:
examples: I'm playing catch-up because of the weeks of training I have missed.

meanings.definition: to have some luck or a lucky opportunity:
examples: The Dodgers couldn't seem to catch a break against Arizona.
He caught a break that few aspiring screenwriters do: running into a studio boss at a party.

meanings.definition: to become ill with a common infection that causes you to cough and sneeze and your nose to run (= drip liquid) or feel blocked:
examples: He caught a cold on holiday.
Stress can lower your immune system, and that makes you more vulnerable to catching colds.
My grandmother used to claim that if you always slept with your windows open you would never catch cold.

meanings.definition: in basketball, to receive a throw from another player and then turn with the ball to face the basket (= goal) to make a shot:
examples: They have versatile players who can catch and face at any point on the court.
The coach has been training her team to catch and face on the perimeter.
She excels at catching and facing the rim from the three-point line.

meanings.definition: a frame with a wire net attached to it that is placed at the entrance to a sewer (= a large pipe for carrying waste away from buildings) to stop large objects from entering the sewer and blocking it:
examples: The local council needs to inspect and clean out catch basins more frequently.
The problem was caused by a build-up of leaves in the catch basins along the street.

meanings.definition: to start burning:
examples: For reasons which are not yet known, the factory caught fire late yesterday evening.
Investigators say that an electric heater caught fire while the man was sleeping.
A large-capacity dryer had caught fire at the hotel, causing $20,000 in damage.
A witness reported that the aircraft's left engine had caught fire just seconds after take-off.
He blew on the spark until the kindling underneath caught fire.
Arson was the only possible cause for the house catching on fire, he said.

meanings.definition: to become fashionable or popular:
examples: I wonder if the game will ever catch on with young people?

meanings.definition: to understand, especially after a long time:
examples: He doesn't take hints very easily, but he'll catch on (to what you're saying) eventually.

meanings.definition: to become fashionable or popular:
examples: Why did the electronic gadget catch on so fast?

meanings.definition: to understand:
examples: We were teasing Jim, but he was slow to catch on that we were joking.

meanings.definition: to become popular:
examples: He invented a type of virtual reality helmet, but it never caught on.
Online trading has been slow to catch on in this part of the country.

meanings.definition: to understand something:
examples: Younger people catch on right away. It is older people that need to be convinced.
They are slowly catching on to the fact that this decision has made them very unpopular.

meanings.definition: to see something only for a moment:
examples: I caught sight of someone with red hair and knew it was you.

catch-sight-of-catch-a-glimpse-of.name: catch sight of/catch a glimpse of

meanings.definition: to manage to see something for a short time:
examples: We caught sight of a rabbit as it hopped into the bushes.
I caught a glimpse of her red coat in the crowd.
She caught sight of her reflection in the mirror and thought how weary she looked.
As I turned the corner, I caught sight of a fox.
I caught a glimpse of her blonde hair.
We stood outside the church, hoping to catch a glimpse of the bride.

meanings.definition: to stay outside in the sun for a period of time:
examples: I'm going out to catch a few rays before lunch.
The resort has a nice little terrace where you can catch some rays as you sip a cooling drink.
I'm going to head to the beach and catch a few rays before it gets too hot.
After a swim, you can lie on a towel and catch a few rays.
There are a couple of loungers by the pool where you can catch some rays, if that's your thing.
It's a popular spot for catching some rays.

meanings.definition: If someone is caught napping, something happens to that person that they are not prepared for:
examples: The goalkeeper was caught napping and the ball went straight in.

meanings.definition: to surprise someone by doing something that they are not expecting or ready for
to surprise someone, esp. in a way that makes the person feel confused or uncertain:
examples: The news caught her completely off guard – she didn't know what to say.
The strength of the storm caught many residents by surprise.

meanings.definition: to do something when someone is not ready for it and is not able to deal with it:
examples: I'm afraid you've caught me on the hop - I wasn't expecting you until next week.

catch-on-the-wrong-foot.name: catch someone on the wrong foot

meanings.definition: If something catches you on the wrong foot, you are not prepared for it:
examples: I hadn't expected the question and it caught me on the wrong foot.

meanings.definition: to show that someone is doing wrong:
examples: I suspected he wasn't telling me the truth, and one day I caught him out when I found some letters he'd written.

meanings.definition: to trick someone into making a mistake:
examples: The examiner will try to catch you out, so stay calm and think carefully before you speak.

meanings.definition: to put someone in a difficult situation:
examples: A lot of people were caught out by the sudden change in the weather.

meanings.definition: to unexpectedly cause difficulty for someone:
examples: The interest rate is very competitive and fixed for the term, so borrowers won't get caught out by rising interest rates.

meanings.definition: to discover someone while they are doing something bad or illegal:
examples: He was caught red-handed taking money from the till.

meanings.definition: to give someone the latest news or information about something:
examples: Can someone catch me up on the latest developments?

meanings.definition: to do something that you have not been able to do recently:
examples: I have to catch up on my reading.

catch-with-pants-trousers-down.name: catch someone with their pants/trousers down

meanings.definition: to discover someone doing something that they want to keep secret, usually something sexual

catch-attention-imagination-interest-etc.name: catch someone's attention, imagination, interest, etc.

meanings.definition: to make someone notice something and feel interested:
examples: A ship out at sea caught his attention.
Her pictures caught my imagination.
One paragraph in particular caught my attention.
The history of the area caught the imagination of the poet.
Isabel was bending over, looking at something, and I wondered what had caught her interest.
A story on the local news caught my interest.

meanings.definition: to get someone's attention:
examples: A sudden movement caught my eye.
I tried to catch the waiter's eye, so we could order.
It was the unusual colour of his jacket that caught my eye.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to notice something or someone:
examples: I was looking around the store for a present for my mom, and this book caught my eye.

meanings.definition: If something catches the light, a light shines on it and makes it look shiny:
examples: She was wearing a spectacular silver gown whose sequins caught the light.
His gold rings catch the light as he waves.
The gold in her dress shimmered as it caught the light.
He shook his head sadly, his silver hair catching the light.
Something on the riverbank caught the light and drew my attention.
She looked across at me, her glasses suddenly catching the light.

meanings.definition: to put a letter into a letterbox (= a container in the street) before the time in the day when the letters are collected from it:
examples: You'll have to run if you want to catch the post.
I rushed out to catch the post with Katie's birthday card.

meanings.definition: If you have caught the sun, the sun has made your skin a slightly darker brown or red colour:
examples: You've caught the sun on the back of your neck.
You've caught the sun on your nose.
I'm feeling a bit sore where I caught the sun.
She's caught the sun on the back of her legs.
You've caught the sun on your shoulders and they're starting to look a bit pink.
You must have been outdoors today - you've really caught the sun.

meanings.definition: If something bad that you have done or that has been happening to you catches up with you, it begins to cause problems for you:
examples: His lies will catch up with him one day.

meanings.definition: If people in authority catch up with you, they discover that you have been doing something wrong and often punish you for it:
examples: They had been selling stolen cars for years before the police caught up with them.

meanings.definition: to communicate with someone by talking in person or on the phone or by exchanging messages, and learn or discuss what has been happening in their life:
examples: She spends hours on the phone, catching up with old friends.
I must catch up with you some time.

meanings.definition: to pause or rest for a short time until you can breathe comfortably or regularly again:
examples: I had to stop running to catch my breath.
In those days, I could run up several flights of stairs without even stopping to catch my breath.
He'd been struggling to catch his breath after leaving the pitchfield.
Let me just catch my breath and I'll be with you in a moment.
No, no, stop and get your breath. I'll run back to the shops for you.
Wait - I just need to get my breath back for a moment.

meanings.definition: to stop breathing for a moment, or to begin to breathe correctly again after running or other exercise:
examples: I had to sit down and catch my breath.
If the exercises are too much, go ahead and stop to catch your breath before continuing.
One minute - I need to catch my breath.
She'd been struggling to catch her breath after leaving the field.
My poor uncle can't take more than a few steps without pausing to catch his breath.
"We gave a great performance," said Green, still catching his breath.

meanings.definition: to catch a very bad cold because you are not wearing warm or dry clothes, etc.
an impossible situation where you are prevented from doing one thing until you have done another thing that you cannot do until you have done the first thing:
examples: a catch-22 situation

meanings.definition: a situation in which there are only two possibilities, and you cannot do either because each depends on having done the other first
a difficult situation in which the solution to a problem is impossible because it is also the cause of the problem:
examples: But it is a catch-22 situation - you can't get people without funding, but you can't get funding without the people there in the first place.

meanings.definition: general and intended to include everything:
examples: "Emerging writer" is a catch-all phrase used for a writer who has yet to publish a book.
"South London" is a catch-all term for anywhere south of the river.

meanings.definition: a very general description that is intended to include everything or many different things:
examples: "Graffiti" is used as a catch-all for a lot of things, from incredible street art to annoying scribbles.
Reasons given for monitoring our communications could be terrorism, drug-dealing, serious crime, tax evasion and that greatest of catch-alls, "the national interest".

meanings.definition: a phrase that can be used to include all the different members of a particular group:
examples: "Emerging writer" is a catch-all phrase used for a writer who has yet to publish a book.
The company decided to use the catch-all phrase "Happy Holidays" instead of "Merry Christmas" on its advertisement.

meanings.definition: a general expression that can be used to include all the members of a particular group:
examples: Culture is a catch-all term that covers many things.
"South London" is a catch-all term for anywhere south of the river.

meanings.definition: a system for watching TV programmes after they have been broadcast, using a computer, phone, etc. that is connected to the internet:
examples: Catch-up TV allows people who miss a programme to view it on demand.
You can still watch it on catch-up TV.

meanings.definition: to sleep:
examples: All I want to do is go home and catch some z's.

meanings.definition: to make yourself ill by getting too cold:
examples: She'll catch pneumonia going out without a coat in this weather!
Maybe he'll get soaking wet and catch pneumonia.
You'd probably catch pneumonia if you swam in this lake.
You'll get pneumonia if you stand around without any clothes on.
Let's go inside - we're in danger of getting pneumonia out here.

meanings.definition: to understand the general meaning of what someone is saying:
examples: She could see from his expression that he caught her drift immediately.
You can make a point quite subtly and you know that the audience will get your drift.
I suspect she didn't catch your drift.
It took me a moment but then I caught his drift.
I didn't hear everything you said but I think I got your drift.

meanings.definition: to start holding something or someone:
examples: He took hold of one end of the carpet and tugged.
I just managed to grab hold of Lucy before she fell in the pool.
When I tried to leave, he grabbed hold of my arm and begged me to stay.
I tried to catch hold of his coat.
She managed to get hold of one of the children as they raced around the living room.

meanings.definition: in baseball, the player who catches the ball if the batter fails to hit it
(in baseball) a player who catches the ball when it is thrown to the player who is hitting for the opposing team
If an illness is catching, it can easily be passed from one person to another:
examples: Flu is catching, so stay away from work.

meanings.definition: (of an illness) able to be given to someone else:
examples: I’ve got a rash, but I don’t think it’s catching.

meanings.definition: the area of land from which water flows into a river, lake, or reservoir:
examples: There has been a lot of recent rainfall in the catchment area of the river.
Deforestation in the lake's catchment areas is endangering the lake.
the large area of native forest in the Georges River catchment

meanings.definition: the area served by a school:
examples: They want their son to go to St Mary's, but they're not in the catchment area.
The school has a very small catchment area of only about a mile radius.
Catchments for local primary schools are fairly small.

meanings.definition: the area served by a hospital or medical centre:
examples: If there's a treatment centre you'd rather go to, don't be put off if you're told you're not in the catchment area.

meanings.definition: the action of burning body tissue using heat or a chemical, to stop an injury from bleeding or getting infected, or to remove harmful cells:

meanings.definition: to burn body tissue using heat or a chemical, to stop an injury from bleeding or getting infected, or to remove harmful cells:

meanings.definition: to stop something from causing someone to feel emotion, especially a negative emotion:
examples: Years of silence cauterized their feelings about the war but these wounds have now reopened.

meanings.definition: careful attention:

meanings.definition: to warn someone about a possible problem or danger:
examples: They cautioned her not to walk through the park at night.

meanings.definition: care and attention in order to avoid risk or possible problems:
examples: The latest figures suggest that consumer caution has increased in recent months.

examples: Economists caution that retail sales tax collections represent about half of all retail spending.

meanings.definition: in motor sport, a yellow flag used to tell the drivers in a race to drive carefully because of some danger on the track:
examples: Officials waved the caution flag because a tyre had rolled onto the track.

meanings.definition: a sign that something bad could happen if you are not careful:
examples: Some observers waved caution flags over the way the poll was conducted.

meanings.definition: an amount of money that someone has to pay when they rent property, use a service, etc. which will not be returned if they damage something or owe money at the end of their contract:
examples: Each new student is required to pay a deposit of $300 as caution money on first registration.

meanings.definition: to warn someone not to do something:
examples: I would caution you against taking these reports too seriously.

meanings.definition: to tell someone that doing something is not a good idea:
examples: Many economists caution against reading too much into one month's report.

meanings.definition: giving a warning
a story that gives a warning:
examples: His career is recalled today as a cautionary tale of economic mismanagement.

Someone who is cautious avoids risks:
examples: He's a cautious driver.

meanings.definition: A cautious action is careful, well considered, and sometimes slow or uncertain:
examples: a cautious approach
cautious criticism

meanings.definition: not acting quickly in order to avoid risks; careful:
examples: Most doctors are cautious about advising you to have surgery.
Auto companies are taking a cautious approach toward introducing electric cars.

meanings.definition: very careful about what you do or say and unwilling to take risks because you want to avoid possible problems:
examples: Businesses have become cautious about spending on technology.
He said the group would continue its cautious approach to expanding in Japan until it better understood the market.

meanings.definition: a feeling that there are some reasons to hope for a good result, even if you do not expect complete success or improvement:
examples: Environmental groups are expressing cautious optimism that an agreement to protect the area can be reached.
A spokesperson for the governor expressed cautious optimism that the plan could work.
Activists have greeted the announcement with cautious optimism.
Economists have reacted to the news with cautious optimism.
Campaigners against the development voiced cautious optimism yesterday, saying that at last their voices were being heard.

meanings.definition: in a careful and well-considered way that avoids risk:
examples: He moved slowly and cautiously along the dark rocky path.
She said cautiously, "You may be right."
He urged the company to proceed cautiously with changes.

meanings.definition: feeling that there are some reasons to hope for a good result, even if you do not expect complete success or improvement:
examples: He said he was cautiously optimistic, predicting some growth in the new year.
We are cautiously optimistic about our prospects of winning the case.
She remains cautiously optimistic about the company's future.
A spokesperson sounded cautiously optimistic that an agreement could be reached.
The legislation doesn't contain the sweeping changes we had hoped for, but I'm cautiously optimistic.
I would describe us as feeling cautiously optimistic about the situation.

meanings.definition: behaviour that avoids risk and is well considered, and sometimes slow or uncertain:
examples: Her cautiousness sometimes makes her slow to reach decisions.
We have seen more cautiousness in spending.
You see cautiousness about making a job change when economic times are uncertain.

meanings.definition: a white sparkling wine (= one with bubbles), produced in Spain, especially in Catalonia
a line of people, vehicles, horses, etc. following a particular route as part of a ceremony
not considering other people's feelings or safety:

meanings.definition: a supporter of the king in the English Civil War in the 1640s

meanings.definition: in a way that does not consider other people's feelings or safety :

meanings.definition: a large hole in the side of a hill, cliff, or mountain, or underground:
