meanings.definition: to remove authority in a system, company, country, etc. from local places to one central place so that the whole system, etc. is under central control:
examples: Payment of bills is now centralized (= organized at one place instead of several).

meanings.definition: to bring separate parts together so that they are organized or controlled from one place:
examples: The law centralized control over the banking industry.

meanings.definition: to organize a system, company, government, etc. so that all of its parts are controlled by one main system or authority:
examples: In an effort to increase profits, the company plans to centralize its production facilities.
We know that we need to centralize, but we're not quite ready to do that yet.

meanings.definition: controlled by one main system or authority:
examples: Republicans criticized the proposal, saying it would expand the power of a centralized government or raise costs imposed on business.
It's important for merging businesses to have a unified, centralized system of telecommunication.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         centralize
to remove authority in a system, company, country, etc. from local places to one central place so that the whole system, etc. is under central control:
examples: Payment of bills is now centralized (= organized at one place instead of several).

meanings.definition: in, at, from, or near the centre or most important part of something:
examples: centrally located

meanings.definition: from one main place:
examples: centrally managed

meanings.definition: near the center:
examples: We want a hotel that’s centrally located.

meanings.definition: the middle point or part:
examples: There was a large table in the centre of the room.
There is a regular bus service between the castle and the town centre.

meanings.definition: a place or building, especially one where a particular activity happens:
examples: a sports/leisure/health centre
a garden/shopping centre
Grants will be given to establish centres of excellence (= places where a particular activity is done extremely well) in this field of research.

meanings.definition: in team sports including rugby, basketball, and netball, a player who plays mainly in the middle part of the playing area, or this position in a team:
examples: With access to more of the court than any other player, a centre can have a huge influence on a netball game.
Johnson can play at centre or second-row.

meanings.definition: in American football, a player who plays in the middle of the line:
examples: He played nearly 60 games at centre and linebacker.

meanings.definition: in baseball, the central part of the outfield (= the part of the field that is the longest distance away from the batter):
examples: That would give us our best defensive outfield, with great coverage in centre.

meanings.definition: in sports including football, hockey, and ice hockey, the area in the middle of the playing area, at an equal distance between the two goals:
examples: I can play in the centre, on the right, and occasionally on the left side.

meanings.definition: in politics, the people in a group who hold opinions that are not extreme but are between two opposites:
examples: His political views are known to be left of centre.
She is considered to be too right of centre to win the nomination.
a centre left party

meanings.definition: to put something in the middle of an area:
examples: Centre (= put at equal distances from the left and right sides of the page) all the headings in this document.

meanings.definition: in football, to kick the ball across the playing area to another player in front of the goal:
examples: Saka unselfishly centred for James to tap home.
She drifted past the defender and centred the ball but there was no one in the penalty box.

meanings.definition: a building, office, etc. that is used for a particular business or activity:
examples: a conference centre
The retailer has a customer service centre in Dundee and distribution centres in Dundee and Livingston.

meanings.definition: an area, city, or country which is known for a particular business or activity and where a lot of business, etc. takes place:
examples: Hong Kong has long been recognized as a centre for the production of jade jewellery.
Dubai is acknowledged to be the commercial centre of the Middle East.

meanings.definition: the main part of a town or city, where most of its offices, stores, etc. are:
examples: Most commuters travel into the city centre by public transport.

meanings.definition: to have something as the main subject of discussion or interest:
examples: The discussion centred around reducing waste.

meanings.definition: the circle marked in the centre of a football pitch or a basketball court
in sports such as football and hockey, the area in the centre of the playing area, at an equal distance between the two goals:
examples: He skipped between two players in centre field to create a scoring chance.
I controlled the ball in centre field and ran towards the goal.

meanings.definition: in baseball, the central part of the outfield (= the part of the field that is the longest distance away from the batter):
examples: He hit the ball over the fence in centre field.
The ball dribbled into centrefield.

meanings.definition: in baseball, a fielder (= a player who tries to catch or stop the ball) who stands in the central part of the outfield (= the part of the field that is the longest distance away from the batter):
examples: He is the centre fielder for the New York Yankees.
The centre fielder caught the ball and made a good throw back to the infield.

meanings.definition: in some team sports such as football, the player in the middle of the front row of forwards (= players who try to score goals)
on a football team, one of two defenders who play in the middle of the pitch and form part of the back four:
examples: Like most centre halfs, McCauley is well over six feet tall.

meanings.definition: a place where a particular activity is done extremely well:
examples: Grants will be given to establish centres of excellence in this field of research.
My first priority is to make this school a centre of excellence.

meanings.definition: a place or an organization that is known for doing a particular activity very well, and that is involved in new developments, new ways of working, etc.:
examples: Eight Chilean scientific centres of excellence have won new funding to strengthen and expand their activities.

meanings.definition: the point in an object or person where their weight is balanced:
examples: The car is more pleasant to drive thanks to a lower centre of gravity and a better chassis.
A crouched position keeps your centre of gravity lower.

meanings.definition: the most central or important part of something, which its other parts are considered in relation to:
examples: The party's centre of gravity has shifted to the right.

meanings.definition: the solid white circle in the centre of a football pitch where the ball is placed before starting a game
the two pages opposite each other in the middle of a newspaper or magazine, which usually deal only with one particular subject and include many pictures:
examples: Tomorrow's edition will include a centre spread on the Spanish royal family.

meanings.definition: the middle of a theatre stage
a situation in which someone or something receives a lot of attention:
examples: She is reluctant to share centre stage with anyone.

meanings.definition: giving the most attention to a particular type of person:
examples: people-centred management policies
a user-centred approach to web design

meanings.definition: a large photograph that covers the two pages opposite each other in the middle of a magazine, usually of a young woman with few or no clothes on, or the person who appears in such a picture
the most important or attractive part or feature of something:
examples: The reduction of crime levels is the centrepiece of the president's domestic policies.
The centrepiece of the shopping centre is a giant fountain.

meanings.definition: a decorative object put in the centre of a table, especially for a formal meal

plural of 
        
         centre of gravity   UK
central, or having a centre:
examples: There are two opposing centric forces that may well be irreconcilable.
Transfers of income and property within the family may be centric or non-centric.

meanings.definition: relating to a nerve centre (= a group of nerves with a particular function)
used by dentists to describe the way a person's upper and lower teeth come together in their mouth:
examples: Your chewing muscles can play a major role in allowing your joints to move symmetrically into the centric relation position.
Centric occlusion is a functional relationship of the teeth.

meanings.definition: having a particular type of person, place, or thing as your most important interest; seen from the point of view of a particular type of person, place, or thing:
examples: The stores' customer-centric approach has yielded dividends.
The picture of British attitudes is clearly more complex than a London-centric view would lead us to conclude.
We need computers to be able to assist people in a humancentric way.

meanings.definition: (of a turning object) moving away from the point around which it is turning:
examples: centrifugal force

meanings.definition: a machine that turns a container round very quickly, causing the solids and liquids inside it to separate by centrifugal action

present participle of 
        
         centre
to put something in the middle of an area:
examples: Centre (= put at equal distances from the left and right sides of the page) all the headings in this document.

meanings.definition: in football, to kick the ball across the playing area to another player in front of the goal:
examples: Saka unselfishly centred for James to tap home.
She drifted past the defender and centred the ball but there was no one in the penalty box.

meanings.definition: (of a turning object) moving towards the point around which it is turning:
examples: centripetal force

meanings.definition: describes a turning object that is moving toward the point around which it is turning
political beliefs or policies that are at the centre of the range of political opinions:
examples: His strategy generally values consensus and centrism over ideology.
The new Prime Minister was urged to move leftwards, away from his predecessor's centrism.

meanings.definition: the fact of having a particular type of person, place, or thing as your most important interest; the quality of being seen from the point of view of a particular type of person, place, or thing:
examples: The Academy has been accused of Eurocentrism and gender bias.
The artist's newest ventures embody his commitment to ecocentrism.

meanings.definition: supporting the centre of the range of political opinions
someone who supports the centre of the range of political opinions:
examples: The policy will alienate independents and centrists.
Her campaign so far suggests that she would try to bridge the divide between the party's liberals and centrists.

meanings.definition: not extreme in your political opinions:
examples: He said all the things that centrist voters seem to want to hear.

meanings.definition: the round, solid part in the centre of a vertebra (= one of the small bones that form the spine) in people and animals:
examples: The centrum of the larger dorsal vertebra is broader.
The swimbladder is situated far back, between the fifth and eighth centra.

meanings.definition: an officer in the army of ancient Rome who was responsible for 100 soldiers
a period of 100 years:
examples: The city centre has scarcely changed in over a century.
This sculpture must be centuries old.
Her medical career spanned half a century.

meanings.definition: a period of 100 years counted from what is believed to be the year of the birth of Jesus Christ:
examples: Rome was founded in the eighth century BC (= before Christ).
He's an expert on 15th-century Italian art.

meanings.definition: a score of 100 runs (= points) in cricket:
examples: Both captains scored centuries.
His third Test century came from only 135 balls.

meanings.definition: a period of 100 years:
examples: Her medical career spanned half a century.

meanings.definition: A century is also a particular period of 100 years:
examples: the fourth century B.C.
His music was influential in the 19th and 20th centuries.

meanings.definition: a type of agave found in Mexico that takes many years to grow and then produces flowers only once before it dies:
examples: There is little water in the basin, which has mesquite trees, century plants, and prickly pear cacti fighting for what little moisture is available.
The century plant is a member of the same family as asparagus.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         chief executive officer  : the person with the most important position in a company
abbreviation for chief executive officer
abbreviation for Chief Executive Officer: the main person responsible for managing a company, who is sometimes also the company's president or chairman of the board:
examples: Selling and Administrative units are headed-up by Senior Vice Presidents who report directly to the CEO.

meanings.definition: a type of mushroom that is considered to be very good to eat
in a position that is towards the head or top part of the body:
examples: Manually tilt the pelvis cephalad by about 15 degrees.
This venous channel continued cephalad through the diaphragm.

meanings.definition: relating to the head:
examples: cephalic disorders

meanings.definition: an animal such as an octopus or squid, that has tentacles (= long parts like arms) around the head
made from clay that has been shaped and then baked until hard:
examples: ceramic tiles

meanings.definition: clay that has been shaped and then baked until hard:
examples: The robot is made of metal, ceramic, and other materials.

meanings.definition: the art of making objects by shaping pieces of clay and then baking them until they are hard
the objects produced by shaping and baking clay, especially when considered as art
objects produced by shaping pieces of clay that are then hardened by baking, or the skill of making such objects
a plant that is grown to produce grain:
examples: cereal crops

meanings.definition: a food that is made from grain and eaten with milk, especially in the morning:
examples: breakfast cereals

meanings.definition: a food made from grain that is eaten esp. for breakfast:
examples: Do you want cereal or eggs?

meanings.definition: a type of grass that is grown to produce grain:
examples: Wheat, rice, and corn are cereals.

meanings.definition:
plural of 
        
         cerebellum   specialized
relating to the cerebellum (= the part of the brain that controls muscles, movement, and balance)
a condition in which part of the cerebellum (= the part of the brain that controls muscles, movement, and balance) pushes through a hole in the base of the skull
a Latin word meaning "of the cerebellum", used in medical names and descriptions
a physical problem present from birth in which part of the brain is pushed through the opening for the spinal cord at the base of the skull, blocking the flow of fluid into the brain and spinal cord
a large part at the back of the brain that controls your muscles, movement, and balance
a large part at the back of the brain that controls the muscles, movement, and balance

plural of 
        
         cerebrum   specialized
relating to the brain or the cerebrum:
examples: He suffered a cerebral haemorrhage.
The patients frequently had a history of disease leading to cerebral damage.

meanings.definition: demanding or involving careful thinking and mental effort rather than feelings:
examples: She makes cerebral films that deal with important social issues.
Chess is cerebral; video games are visceral.

meanings.definition: intelligent and serious, and enjoying serious thought rather than emotion:
examples: His problem wasn't his policies; it was his personality. He was simply too cerebral and too out of touch with Middle America.

meanings.definition: relating to the brain, esp. the front part of the brain
the grey outer layer of the cerebrum, responsible for language, thinking, creating new ideas, etc.
one of the two halves of the cerebrum, each of which controls the opposite side of the body
a physical condition involving permanent tightening of the muscles that is caused by damage to the brain around or before the time of birth
a physical condition involving permanent tightening of the muscles that is caused by damage to the brain during or before birth
in a way that demands or involves careful thinking and mental effort rather than feelings :
examples: When disaster happened, he reacted emotionally rather than cerebrally.
There was a lot of cerebrally satisfying conversation about art and politics.

meanings.definition: stupid:
examples: I have heard quite enough about his ex-wife and her cerebrally challenged new husband.
There's a belief among the cerebrally challenged that wearing spectacles will somehow make them appear more intelligent.

meanings.definition: the operation of the brain
the process of thinking
of or connected with the brain
relating to both the brain and the spine:
examples: cerebrospinal fluid

meanings.definition: a liquid that moves in and around the brain and spinal cord (= the nerves inside the spine):
examples: The brain itself is surrounded by cerebrospinal fluid.
Regular samples of blood, urine and cerebrospinal fluid will be taken to look for biological markers.

meanings.definition: relating to the blood vessels, especially the arteries, that supply the brain:
examples: Passive smoking is considered a major cause of cerebrovascular disease, which causes strokes.

meanings.definition: the front part of the brain, that is involved with thought, decision, emotion, and character
the front part of the brain, which is involved with thought, decision, emotion, and character
a county (= an area with its own local government) in central western Wales:
examples: Aberystwyth is a university and resort town in Ceredigion, Wales.

meanings.definition: related to, used in, or involving a ceremony (= a fixed set of formal acts performed on important social or religious occasions):
examples: A Marine honour guard flanks the president during ceremonial events at the White House.
The men were dressed in ceremonial black robes.

meanings.definition: (a set of) formal acts, often fixed and traditional, performed on important social or religious occasions:
examples: Westminster Abbey is used for ceremonials.
Mounted troopers perform a spectacular piece of ceremonial.

meanings.definition: in a way that relates to or is part of a ceremony (= a fixed set of formal acts performed on important social or religious occasions):
examples: The store will be ceremonially reopened with a ribbon cutting and appearances from top designers.
The ritual purifies the meat ceremonially.

meanings.definition: Ceremonious behaviour is very or too formal or polite.
in a way that is very formal or polite:
examples: He shook hands ceremoniously with each of his supporters as they arrived.
Officials ceremoniously broke ground for a new building.

meanings.definition: (a set of) formal acts, often fixed and traditional, performed on important social or religious occasions:
examples: a wedding/graduation ceremony

meanings.definition: very formal and polite behaviour:
examples: She arrived at the airport without the pomp and ceremony that usually accompanies important politicians.
I handed her my letter of resignation without ceremony (= in an informal way).

meanings.definition: a set of acts, often traditional or religious, performed at a formal occasion esp. to recognize an important event, or the performing of such acts:
examples: a graduation/wedding ceremony
She was buried without ceremony.

meanings.definition: in Roman mythology (= ancient stories), the goddess (= female god) of grain and the harvest (= the time when crops are cut):
examples: Ceres is the goddess of grain from which we get the word cereal.

meanings.definition: a dark reddish-pink colour
If someone or something is a cert for something or to do something, he, she, or it is certain to get it or do it:
examples: With all her experience she's a dead cert for the job.
She looks like a cert for Best Actress in her first film.
The Russian team is a cert to win the gold medal.

meanings.definition:
written abbreviation for
        
         certificate
having no doubt or knowing exactly that something is true, or known to be true, correct, exact, or effective:
examples: Are you absolutely certain (that) you gave them the right number?
I feel certain (that) you're doing the right thing.
You should make certain (that) everyone understands the instructions.
The police seem certain (that) they will find the people responsible for the attack.
I'm not certain how much it will cost.
He was quite certain about his attacker's identity.
I've never been more certain of anything in my whole life.
One thing is certain - she won't resign willingly.

meanings.definition: impossible to avoid or extremely likely:
examples: The population explosion is certain to cause widespread famine.
Oil prices are certain to rise following the agreement to limit production.
After all his hard work, he's certain to pass his exams.
The team looks almost certain to win the match.
It is virtually certain (that) she will win the gold medal.
It is almost certain (that) there will be another vote.
Even if a ceasefire can be agreed, how can they make certain (that) neither side breaks it?
Cancer sufferers no longer face certain death as they once did.
This scandal will mean certain defeat for the party in the election.

meanings.definition: named but neither famous nor known well:
examples: I had lunch today with a certain Will Smith - not the Will Smith, I should explain.

meanings.definition: limited:
examples: I like modern art to a certain extent, but I don't like the really experimental stuff.
Technology can improve the situation to a certain degree.

meanings.definition: particular but not named or described:
examples: We have certain reasons for our decision, which have to remain confidential.
Do you think war is justifiable in certain circumstances?
Certain members of the audience may disagree with what I'm about to say.

meanings.definition: some:
examples: Certain of the candidates were well below the usual standard, but others were very good indeed.

meanings.definition: knowing that something is true or will happen and having no cause to feel that it may not be true or may not happen; having no doubt:
examples: "I think Emily is going to pick up Judy." "Are you certain?"
One thing is certain – supporters of the bill are not giving up.
I’m certain (that) he’ll be there.
I’m not certain how much it will cost.
When you report a robbery, make certain a police report is filled out (= check that this happens).

meanings.definition: particular but not named or described:
examples: Parents expect their kids to leave home at a certain point.

meanings.definition: some but not exactly stated; limited:
examples: She enjoys sports to a certain extent.
There’s a certain amount of exaggeration in all ads.

meanings.definition: used to reply completely or to emphasize something and show that there is no doubt about it:
examples: She certainly had a friend called Mark, but I don't know whether he was her boyfriend.
"This is rather a difficult question." "Yes, it's certainly not easy."
"Do you think more money should be given to education?" "Certainly!"
"Had you forgotten about our anniversary?" "Certainly not! I've reserved a table at Michel's restaurant for this evening."

meanings.definition: used when agreeing or disagreeing strongly to a request:
examples: "Could you lend me £10?" "Certainly."
"Did you take any money out of my purse?" "Certainly not!"

meanings.definition: very likely to happen:
examples: She will certainly win the election if the opinion polls are accurate.

meanings.definition: When said in answer to a question asking for help, certainly means yes:
examples: "Can you give me a hand?" "Certainly."

meanings.definition: the state of being completely confident or having no doubt about something:
examples: I'm unable to answer that question with any certainty.

meanings.definition: something that cannot be doubted:
examples: There are few absolute certainties in life.

meanings.definition: something that is very likely to happen:
examples: Joan will win - that's a certainty.
Joan is a certainty to win.

meanings.definition: the sure knowledge that something is true:
examples: Can you say with absolute certainty that this is the man you saw?

meanings.definition: something that has no possibility of any other result; something that you know will happen in a particular way:
examples: There are few certainties in life.

meanings.definition: mentally ill
behaving in a silly or stupid way:
examples: Simon's washing his car again - that man's certifiable!

meanings.definition: in a way that can or could be certified (= said or written officially or formally):
examples: The teas, coffees, beers, and a few of the wines are certifiably organic.
The president can overturn even a fair conviction and set a certifiably guilty person free.

meanings.definition: clearly and certainly:
examples: In those days she was certifiably the world's hottest female music star.
They are young, ambitious, and certifiably hip.

meanings.definition: If you say that someone is certifiably insane, you are emphasizing that you think they are behaving in a very silly or stupid way. :
examples: Some of the people on these websites sound certifiably insane.
He would have to be certifiably mad to do anything that might jeopardize his position.
Are you absolutely, certifiably nuts?
This is one of the most certifiably insane decisions the government has ever taken.
These people weren't only irresponsible, they were certifiably crazy.

meanings.definition: an official document that states that the information on it is true:
examples: a birth/marriage/death certificate
a doctor's/medical certificate

meanings.definition: the qualification that you receive when you are successful in an exam:
examples: She has a Certificate in Drama Education.

meanings.definition: to provide an official document as proof that something has happened or been done:
examples: She has proposed a series of reforms to the system of reporting and certificating deaths.
A welder who has been certificated to work at a certain level must be brought in to do the repairs.

meanings.definition: an official document that gives information:
examples: a birth/death/marriage certificate

meanings.definition: an official document that states that the information on it is true, and that is given to someone as proof that they are, have, or own something, or have permission to do something:
examples: Once a company is registered, notice of its certificate of incorporation must be published in a public newspaper.
When you exercise the share option, you receive a certificate stating how many shares your cash fund has purchased.
birth/death/marriage certificate

meanings.definition: a qualification that you receive when you are successful in an examination, or have done a course of training:
examples: She holds a certificate in human resource management from San Francisco State University.

meanings.definition: an online service that makes sure that information that is sent over the internet is kept safe and private:
examples: The most-visited web sites rely on GeoTrust SSL more than any other certificate authority.

meanings.definition: an official document that shows the results of scientific tests on a product such as a food or drug, listing the chemicals, etc. it contains and the quantities of them:
examples: Manufacturers are required by the FDA to provide a certificate of analysis for each product lot number.

meanings.definition: an official document used to prove that you have been to a class or course for special training:
examples: After the conference each participant will receive a certificate of attendance and can claim the European CME credits for his/her participation.

meanings.definition: a document that shows if someone owes money on a property
a document that shows that something obeys a particular law or rule:
examples: Your boat will need a certificate of compliance - like an MOT - which lasts for four years.

meanings.definition: a type of investment in which customers earn interest for saving their money for a fixed period of time, or the document which shows this investment:
examples: 3-month/5-year, etc. certificate of deposit
Interest on variable-rate certificates of deposit will be periodically adjusted in accordance with current market rates.

meanings.definition: certificate of good standing
an official document that is used to prove that someone is still alive so they can receive their pension
an official document that proves that a company exists, does not owe taxes, and is legally allowed to do business in a particular area:
examples: Our company can help you obtain all the relevant certificates for your business, including a certificate of good standing.

meanings.definition: an official document that proves that a company has been legally created and officially exists:
examples: Charities must be registered with the Charity Commission before its trustees may apply for a certificate of incorporation.

meanings.definition:
another name for 
        
         articles of incorporation
an official document from an insurance company, used to prove that you have insurance and to show the types of financial protection that it provides:
examples: Any project that plans to film on state property must file a certificate of insurance with the New Hampshire Film and Television Office.

meanings.definition: an official document that states that a manufacturer has finished making a product and is ready for the buyer to collect or import it
an official document that states where and when something was made:
examples: To qualify for exemption from customs duty, goods must be accompanied by a certificate of manufacture.

meanings.definition: an official document that states that a building is safe to use and may legally be used for a particular purpose:
examples: A certificate of occupancy is required for new inhabited commercial structures.

meanings.definition: an official document that states where a food or product was produced, and by which company:
examples: Importers must present an export certificate and a certificate of origin issued by the relevant authority in the exporting country.

meanings.definition: in the UK, an official document from the post office, used to prove that you have mailed something on a particular date:
examples: In the event your item is lost or damaged in the mail, you will have to present a stamped and signed certificate of posting with your claim for loss.

meanings.definition: an official document from a bank, used to prove that a promissory note was not accepted or that a bill of exchange was not paid
an official document stating that a person or company has provided all the necessary information for an official or government record:
examples: An organization may not market, promote, sell, or distribute a discount medical plan in Nebraska unless the entity holds a certificate of registration issued by the Director of Insurance.

meanings.definition: an official document that provides information about a person or property which has been recorded in public or government records:
examples: You are advised to confirm with your solicitor that an official search has been carried out and a certificate of search has been issued.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         certificate of good standing
having an official document as proof that something has happened or been done:
examples: They offer classes taught by certificated teachers.
Some popular stocks could originally be bought and sold only in certificated form.

meanings.definition: having a certificate, sometimes one that shows that a particular standard has been reached:
examples: certificated stocks

meanings.definition: the process of earning an official document, or the act of providing an official document, as proof that something has happened or been done:

a programme for the certification of X-ray technicians

meanings.definition: proof or a document proving that someone is qualified for a particular job, or that something is of good quality:
examples: Adult workers are increasingly going back to school for a degree or certification to improve their job opportunities.

meanings.definition: the process of giving official or legal approval to a person, company, product, etc. that has reached a particular standard:

certification programme/process/requirements

meanings.definition: an organization that has the power to give official or legal approval to a person, company, product, etc. that has reached a particular standard:
examples: Civil aviation certification authorities all over the world were satisfied with the aircraft's safety.

meanings.definition: having a document that proves that you have successfully finished a course of training:
examples: a certified teacher/nurse

meanings.definition: having a document that proves you have successfully completed a course of training:
examples: a certified teacher

meanings.definition: approved by an official organization to do a particular job because you have successfully completed its examination and proved that you have the necessary training and qualifications:
examples: All certified dental assistants have been certified by the Dental Assisting National Board.
a certified accountant
certified financial planners

meanings.definition: a check that a bank has already paid for
a check that a bank has already paid for
a cheque that a bank has already paid for
a cheque that will certainly be paid because the bank has made sure, and states officially, that there is enough money in the account to pay it:
examples: Fees must be paid by direct deposit, certified cheque or bank draft only.

meanings.definition: a copy of a document that can be used instead of the original one because an official has checked it and formally approved it as a true and accurate copy by signing it:
examples: To open an account, some banks demand a certified copy of your passport and proof of address.

meanings.definition: If a letter is sent by certified mail, the person who receives it must sign their name to show that it has been received.
mail for which proof of delivery is obtained

→ 
        
         recorded delivery  :
